thread.title: Russell Brand Brisbane review: Comic sows seeds of revolution
thread.title_full: Russell Brand Brisbane review: Comic sows seeds of revolution

author: Cameron Atfield
title: Russell Brand Brisbane review: Comic sows seeds of revolution
text:
Russell Brand says there's a revolution coming. Photo: Getty Images 
If the revolution is, indeed, going to be televised, Russell Brand will likely be its host.
The British comic-actor-intellectual-revolutionary brought his stream of consciousness to the Brisbane Entertainment Centre on Thursday night.
In what's part stand-up, part revivalist tent preaching (minus the Bible-thumping Christianity) Brand has a pretty simple message: only by working together can anything be achieved.
Russell Brand joins the crowd during this Trew World Order show in Melbourne last week. Photo: Meredith O'Shea 
Collectivism, he tells the four-and-a-half thousand-odd people in the arena, is the secret to survival.
Advertisement And the best way to achieve collectivism, he says, is to be together.
Add a sexually charged dose of charisma and you have the beginnings of a movement.
Brand is a master of making the personal connections that can make even an arena show seem intimate.
His audience embraces him and Brand embraces them right back.
A walk on the floor, among the crowd, sees him come into contact with many admirers, including a pair of Byron Bay hippies – Firebird and Bratima – and wonders aloud if they have some plans for later on.
"What happens in Byron Bay?" he asks.
"Enlightenment! Freedom!" Bratima replies. "It's where the evolution of man really begins."
Brand: "Yeah well you say 'enlightenment' but I hear 'anal sex'."
That sets a tone for his many interactions, save for a 19-year-old woman he encounters.
"I remember 1996. It doesn't seem like any time ago," he says.
"The Spice Girls, all that stuff, and I was basically walking around with basically this personality.
"You were emerging from a vagina."
A brief pause.
"So was I, to be fair."
Sex, of course, is a constant. After all, for this self-described recovering sex-addict, it provides fertile ground for comedy.
And while there was a serious, philosophical message underpinning his entire performance, Brand is, at his core, a comedian and dick jokes are, at their core, funny.
Even if, or perhaps especially if, the dick in question is attached to Adolf Hitler.
It's hard to keep up with Brand and his critiques of the media, society's power structures, the struggles of the lower classes.
Brand himself admits that can be a problem.
He talks a lot about his search for a coherent voice that he says was so sadly lacking in his infamous 2013 interview with the BBC's Jeremy Paxman.
That interview, Brand says, made him realise he needed to refine his voice, to properly articulate what he sees as a coming revolution.
It's been a challenge and it's made him some enemies, Brand says, including US presidential candidate Donald Trump (who questions Katy Perry's decision to marry Brand in a video played to the audience) and Rupert Murdoch, who cops a particularly unpublishable bollocking.
"I've learnt a few things over the course of the past year," Brand says.
"For example, if you spend your time criticising all media, it's quite difficult to make money in media."
Like any good comedian performing in Brisbane, Brand has done some homework.
Billy Gordon's telephonic escapades rate a mention, as does the infamous suburb of "Woodbridge". Points for trying there at least, Rusty.
But perhaps the highlight belonged to him and poor, confused Margaret sitting at home.
When her daughter, Diana, comes up to the stage (with Brand's consent, it must be said) to spruik her veganism, Brand promptly grabs her phone and calls her mother.
Margaret duly answers.
"I'm calling you to ask for your daughter's hand," he says.
"Not necessarily in marriage; I'll decide what I'll do with it once I've got hold of it."
He then breaks into song.
"Margaret, your daughter, I've just decided to greet.
"Her name's Diana, she is a vegan, but tonight's she's getting some meat."
Brand is manic, but he's not a maniac. Through the maze of seemingly random philosophical musings there is an argument searching for coherence.
Brand makes one wonder exactly what's ticking over in that mind. There's clearly intelligence and there's clearly a genuine desire to make a positive difference.
In the wider community, Brand is a divisive character and it's easy to see why.
An intellectual or a wanker? Sometimes, the line can be a little blurry.
But one thing's for sure – the guy provokes thought.
And the ridiculous 45-minute hellish escape from Boondall's car parks provides plenty of time to devote to those thoughts.
